test_results.evidence_title: Regulations amending the Farm Products Agencies Act come into force, impacting Canadian chicken marketing quotas for production and marketing.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Increase testing of products for compliance with Canadian standards.
semantic_matches.promise_description: This commitment aims to increase the rigorous examination and verification of products sold in Canada to ensure they meet established Canadian safety, quality, environmental, and performance standards, thereby protecting consumers and maintaining market integrity.

commitment_history_rationale.action: The Auditor General of Canada released a report highlighting that Health Canada did not adequately monitor whether companies complied with the Canada Consumer Product Safety Act, noting insufficient inspections to verify compliance and a lack of knowledge regarding the sufficiency of its activities to protect Canadians from unsafe products.

The National Research Council of Canada (NRC) announced it was expanding its testing capacity for personal protective equipment (PPE), including masks and gowns, to help ensure these critical products met Canadian standards during the COVID-19 pandemic.

promise_full.text: Increase testing of products for compliance with Canadian standards.
promise_full.progress_summary: Major progress has been made in increasing the testing of products for compliance with Canadian standards through extensive regulatory updates and enforcement actions. Health Canada has enacted numerous new and amended regulations across various product categories, including consumer products (e.g., surface coatings, carriages, strollers, tents), food (e.g., supplemented foods, feeds, additives, microbiological criteria), medical devices, hazardous products, biocides, pest control products, and cosmetics. Key regulatory changes include new rules for finished product testing under the Food and Drug and Medical Devices Regulations, mandated data submission for vaping products, and a new framework for biocides that includes market authorization and monitoring. Furthermore, significant fines and investigations demonstrate active enforcement of compliance with these updated standards.
promise_full.concise_title: Strengthen Product Testing for Canadian Standards
promise_full.description: This commitment aims to increase the rigorous examination and verification of products sold in Canada to ensure they meet established Canadian safety, quality, environmental, and performance standards, thereby protecting consumers and maintaining market integrity.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Canadians will benefit from enhanced safety and reliability of goods purchased, as more products will have been verified to meet Canada's stringent health, environmental, and performance benchmarks, reducing risks from faulty or unsafe items.
Consumers may experience a higher baseline quality for products across various sectors, leading to greater confidence in purchases and potentially fewer issues requiring returns or repairs.

Businesses, especially importers and manufacturers, might face increased costs and longer timelines for product approval due to more extensive testing requirements, potentially affecting product availability or prices.
While improving consumer safety, this initiative could inadvertently create trade barriers for foreign products, potentially impacting supply chains or limiting consumer choice in niche markets.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Canadians will benefit from enhanced safety and reliability of goods purchased, as more products will have been verified to meet Canada's stringent health, environmental, and performance benchmarks, reducing risks from faulty or unsafe items.
Consumers may experience a higher baseline quality for products across various sectors, leading to greater confidence in purchases and potentially fewer issues requiring returns or repairs.

Businesses, especially importers and manufacturers, might face increased costs and longer timelines for product approval due to more extensive testing requirements, potentially affecting product availability or prices.
While improving consumer safety, this initiative could inadvertently create trade barriers for foreign products, potentially impacting supply chains or limiting consumer choice in niche markets.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: A regulatory commitment increasing testing, with limited direct link to national productivity or investment tenets and likely small economic scale, potentially adding bureaucracy.

semantic_matches.promise_text: As part of a green agricultural plan for Canada, increase support to farmers to develop and adopt agricultural management practices to reduce emissions, store carbon in healthy soil and enhance resiliency; triple funding for clean tech on farms; and reduce methane and fertilizer emissions in the agricultural sector.
semantic_matches.promise_description: This commitment aims to advance Canada's green agricultural plan by increasing support for farmers to adopt sustainable management practices that reduce greenhouse gas emissions and store carbon in soil, while tripling funding for clean agricultural technologies and actively working to cut methane and fertilizer emissions.

commitment_history_rationale.action: The Pan-Canadian Framework on Clean Growth and Climate Change was released, establishing Canada's national climate strategy and identifying agriculture as a sector for action to reduce emissions and enhance carbon sequestration through innovative practices.

The government released 'A Healthy Environment and a Healthy Economy,' Canada's strengthened climate plan, which included specific commitments for agriculture, such as new investments to help farmers adopt practices that reduce emissions, store carbon, enhance resiliency, support clean technologies on farms, and reduce methane emissions.

Budget 2021 allocated significant funding to support agricultural climate action, including $200 million for a new Agricultural Climate Solutions program to help farmers adopt beneficial management practices, and $165.7 million for the Agricultural Clean Technology Program.

promise_full.text: As part of a green agricultural plan for Canada, increase support to farmers to develop and adopt agricultural management practices to reduce emissions, store carbon in healthy soil and enhance resiliency; triple funding for clean tech on farms; and reduce methane and fertilizer emissions in the agricultural sector.
promise_full.progress_summary: The government has made major progress on increasing support for farmers to adopt green agricultural practices and enhance resiliency. Bill C-235, the Building a Green Prairie Economy Act, received Royal Assent, providing a framework for a sustainable Prairie economy. Significant programs have been launched under the Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership, including the $250-million Resilient Agricultural Landscape Program and the Agriculture Resiliency Program ($1.3 million annually), both aimed at supporting producers in conserving landscapes, enhancing resiliency, and addressing climate change. Additionally, new living labs have been established under the Agricultural Climate Solutions program to foster sustainable farming practices, and over $12 million was allocated for beef and forage research. While substantial funding and programs are operational, specific evidence for tripling clean tech funding or explicit targets and progress on agricultural methane and fertilizer emission reductions beyond general sustainable practices is not detailed.
promise_full.concise_title: Support Farmers for Green Agriculture and Emissions Reduction
promise_full.description: This commitment aims to advance Canada's green agricultural plan by increasing support for farmers to adopt sustainable management practices that reduce greenhouse gas emissions and store carbon in soil, while tripling funding for clean agricultural technologies and actively working to cut methane and fertilizer emissions.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Canadians can expect a healthier environment through reduced agricultural pollution, improved air quality, and more carbon sequestration in soils, contributing to Canada's overall climate change goals.
Farmers will gain increased financial and technical support to innovate and adopt sustainable practices, potentially improving their long-term profitability and resilience against climate impacts.

There may be initial adjustments or costs for farmers transitioning to new technologies and practices, which could indirectly affect food production costs or require adaptation periods for the sector.

This initiative signals a shift towards more sustainable food production systems, which could lead to more environmentally conscious food choices and a more resilient domestic food supply for consumers.
promise_full.background_and_context: This commitment stems from the recognition that while agriculture is vital to Canada's economy and food security, it also contributes significantly to greenhouse gas emissions, particularly methane from livestock and nitrous oxide from fertilizers. Farmers are also directly impacted by climate change through extreme weather events. The government aims to support farmers in transitioning to more sustainable, resilient practices, contributing to Canada's broader climate targets, ensuring both environmental stewardship and the sector's long-term competitiveness. This involves both financial incentives and targets for emission reduction, as outlined in both the 2021 and 2025 Liberal platforms.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Canadians can expect a healthier environment through reduced agricultural pollution, improved air quality, and more carbon sequestration in soils, contributing to Canada's overall climate change goals.
Farmers will gain increased financial and technical support to innovate and adopt sustainable practices, potentially improving their long-term profitability and resilience against climate impacts.

There may be initial adjustments or costs for farmers transitioning to new technologies and practices, which could indirectly affect food production costs or require adaptation periods for the sector.

This initiative signals a shift towards more sustainable food production systems, which could lead to more environmentally conscious food choices and a more resilient domestic food supply for consumers.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Supports agricultural tech adoption and practices primarily for environmental goals. Shows limited direct link to national productivity or export growth and unspecified scale of economic impact.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Develop the next agricultural policy framework.
semantic_matches.promise_description: The government commits to developing the next Agricultural Policy Framework, a five-year federal-provincial-territorial agreement, to guide investments and support Canadian farmers in adopting sustainable practices, adapting to climate change, and enhancing competitiveness and food security.

commitment_history_rationale.action: The Prime Minister's Mandate Letter to the Minister of Agriculture and Agri-Food directed the Minister to 'continue to work with provinces and territories to implement the Canadian Agricultural Partnership and begin discussions on the next agricultural policy framework.' This explicitly set the stage for the development of the subsequent framework.

Federal, Provincial, and Territorial (FPT) Ministers of Agriculture concluded their annual meeting, agreeing on a vision for the next agricultural policy framework. This meeting solidified the direction and priorities for the framework that would succeed the Canadian Agricultural Partnership, directly preceding the commitment to develop it.

promise_full.text: Develop the next agricultural policy framework.
promise_full.progress_summary: The government has made major progress by launching the five-year, $3.5 billion Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership (Sustainable CAP) as the next agricultural policy framework. This new framework, operational since 2023, includes six national programs aimed at fostering growth and sustainability. Existing programs like AgriStability, AgriInvest, and AgriInsurance have been amended to align with Sustainable CAP. Furthermore, new initiatives such as the $250-million Resilient Agricultural Landscape Program and the Agriculture Resiliency Program have been launched under this partnership, demonstrating concrete steps towards implementing the new framework and its objectives.
promise_full.description: The government commits to developing the next Agricultural Policy Framework, a five-year federal-provincial-territorial agreement, to guide investments and support Canadian farmers in adopting sustainable practices, adapting to climate change, and enhancing competitiveness and food security.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Farmers may receive enhanced support for adopting sustainable practices and climate change adaptation, potentially leading to more stable incomes and resilient operations.
The framework aims to strengthen Canada's food security by fostering a more productive and environmentally sound agricultural sector, ensuring a reliable domestic food supply.
Canadians could see a positive environmental impact as the framework promotes practices that improve soil health, water quality, and reduce the carbon footprint of farming.
A robust agricultural sector, supported by the new framework, contributes to economic stability and job creation in rural communities across the country.
Consumers may benefit from a more stable and potentially more diverse food supply, though policy choices within the framework could indirectly influence food prices.
promise_full.background_and_context: This commitment stems from the ongoing need to support Canada's vital agricultural sector, which faces significant challenges including climate change impacts, global market competition, and the imperative for sustainable practices. The existing federal-provincial-territorial agricultural policy framework, a multi-year agreement guiding investments in the sector, requires regular renewal to address evolving needs. The government aims to modernize this framework to ensure farmers can adapt to new environmental realities, enhance their competitiveness, and contribute to Canada's food security. This initiative reflects broader policy discussions around climate action, economic resilience, and maintaining a robust food supply chain for all Canadians.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Farmers may receive enhanced support for adopting sustainable practices and climate change adaptation, potentially leading to more stable incomes and resilient operations.
The framework aims to strengthen Canada's food security by fostering a more productive and environmentally sound agricultural sector, ensuring a reliable domestic food supply.
Canadians could see a positive environmental impact as the framework promotes practices that improve soil health, water quality, and reduce the carbon footprint of farming.
A robust agricultural sector, supported by the new framework, contributes to economic stability and job creation in rural communities across the country.
Consumers may benefit from a more stable and potentially more diverse food supply, though policy choices within the framework could indirectly influence food prices.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Developing a national agricultural framework can significantly impact productivity, investment, and exports in a major sector, aligning positively with core tenets.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Undertake a broad review of the current legislative and structural elements that may restrict or hinder competition, including reviewing the mandate of the Commissioner of Competition and ensure that Canadians are protected from anti-consumer practices in critical sectors.
semantic_matches.promise_description: The government commits to a comprehensive examination of laws and structures that impede market competition, alongside a review of the Commissioner of Competition's role, aiming to safeguard Canadians from unfair, anti-consumer practices, particularly in essential industries.

commitment_history_rationale.action: The Competition Bureau released a report titled 'Big Data and Innovation: Implications for Competition Policy in Canada,' examining how the rise of big data and the digital economy presented new challenges for competition policy and enforcement, suggesting the need for adaptation.

The House of Commons Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology (INDU) released its report 'A New and Modern Competition Act for the 21st Century,' recommending a comprehensive review and modernization of the Competition Act to address challenges posed by the digital economy and other sectors.

The Competition Bureau published its report 'Competition in the Canadian Financial Services Sector,' identifying areas where competition could be strengthened to benefit consumers and highlighting the importance of effective competition in critical sectors.

promise_full.text: Undertake a broad review of the current legislative and structural elements that may restrict or hinder competition, including reviewing the mandate of the Commissioner of Competition and ensure that Canadians are protected from anti-consumer practices in critical sectors.
promise_full.description: The government commits to a comprehensive examination of laws and structures that impede market competition, alongside a review of the Commissioner of Competition's role, aiming to safeguard Canadians from unfair, anti-consumer practices, particularly in essential industries.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Canadians may experience lower prices and more choices for goods and services, particularly in critical sectors like groceries, banking, and telecommunications, due to increased market competition.
Enhanced consumer protection measures could shield individuals from predatory pricing, hidden fees, and other unfair business practices, leading to greater financial security and trust.
Businesses, especially larger corporations, might face increased scrutiny and potentially stricter regulations, which could impact their operational flexibility or investment decisions.
The review process itself could be lengthy and complex, meaning tangible benefits for consumers might not be immediately apparent, requiring patience for reforms to take effect.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Canadians may experience lower prices and more choices for goods and services, particularly in critical sectors like groceries, banking, and telecommunications, due to increased market competition.
Enhanced consumer protection measures could shield individuals from predatory pricing, hidden fees, and other unfair business practices, leading to greater financial security and trust.
Businesses, especially larger corporations, might face increased scrutiny and potentially stricter regulations, which could impact their operational flexibility or investment decisions.
The review process itself could be lengthy and complex, meaning tangible benefits for consumers might not be immediately apparent, requiring patience for reforms to take effect.
promise_full.background_and_context: This commitment arises from concerns about the rising cost of living and a perceived lack of effective competition in key Canadian sectors, as highlighted in the 2021 Liberal Platform. The platform explicitly states that "Canadians are paying too much for everyday essentials" and identifies insufficient competition as a contributing factor. The government aims to ensure that markets are fair and competitive, which is expected to drive down prices, foster innovation, and offer more choices. This initiative is particularly aimed at addressing affordability challenges in sectors like telecommunications, banking, and groceries, where Canadians frequently face high costs. Reviewing the Commissioner of Competition's mandate suggests an intent to strengthen the regulatory framework to more effectively combat anti-consumer practices.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Reviewing competition law targets restrictions and inefficiency, aligning with tenets for economic freedom, productivity, and competitiveness. Potential for significant economy-wide impact.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Protect supply-managed agricultural sectors, including by providing full and fair compensation with respect to the Canada-United States-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA) and making this determination within the first year of the mandate.
semantic_matches.promise_description: This commitment aims to safeguard Canada's supply-managed agricultural sectors, which include dairy, poultry, and eggs, by ensuring producers receive full and fair compensation for impacts arising from the Canada-United States-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA) trade deal, with a compensation determination made within the first year of the government's mandate.

commitment_history_rationale.action: Canada, the United States, and Mexico reach an agreement in principle on a modernized trade agreement, later known as CUSMA, which included new market access for U.S. dairy products impacting Canada's supply-managed sectors.

Federal Budget 2019 announces up to $3.9 billion in compensation for supply-managed producers affected by the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) and the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), setting a precedent for future trade agreement impacts.

The Canada-United States-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA) officially enters into force, implementing the new trade rules and market access concessions, including those directly impacting Canada's supply-managed sectors.

The Government of Canada announces the second phase of compensation for dairy farmers for CETA and CPTPP impacts, and reiterates its commitment to provide full and fair compensation for the impacts of CUSMA.

promise_full.text: Protect supply-managed agricultural sectors, including by providing full and fair compensation with respect to the Canada-United States-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA) and making this determination within the first year of the mandate.
promise_full.progress_summary: Major progress has been made towards protecting supply-managed agricultural sectors and providing CUSMA compensation. In June 2023, the government authorized $1.2 billion in grants to dairy producers and $295 million to dairy processors to compensate for income and market losses related to the Canada-United States-Mexico Agreement. A Dairy Innovation and Investment Fund was also announced to assist processors. Additionally, numerous regulations have been enacted and amended under the Farm Products Agencies Act, continuously adjusting marketing quotas for chicken, turkey, and eggs to manage supply and protect these sectors. While significant compensation has been provided, the determination was made in 2023, beyond the first year of the mandate.
promise_full.concise_title: Protect Supply Management & CUSMA Compensation for Farmers
promise_full.description: This commitment aims to safeguard Canada's supply-managed agricultural sectors, which include dairy, poultry, and eggs, by ensuring producers receive full and fair compensation for impacts arising from the Canada-United States-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA) trade deal, with a compensation determination made within the first year of the government's mandate.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Farmers in supply-managed sectors will receive financial support to offset market access concessions from CUSMA, stabilizing their income and ensuring the viability of their operations against international competition.
Canadians may continue to experience stable prices for dairy, poultry, and egg products due to the managed supply system, which aims to balance producer income with consumer access to goods.

Taxpayers will bear the financial cost of this compensation, as public funds are allocated to support these specific agricultural industries, which could otherwise be directed to other public services.
This policy reinforces Canada's commitment to its supply management system, potentially influencing future trade negotiations where other nations might seek further market liberalization.

It contributes to domestic food security by supporting the continued operation of Canadian farms in these key sectors, potentially reducing reliance on imported goods and ensuring a stable domestic supply.
promise_full.background_and_context: This commitment addresses concerns from Canada's supply-managed agricultural sectors (dairy, poultry, eggs) regarding the impacts of international trade agreements. The Canada-United States-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA), like its predecessor the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), included provisions that opened up a portion of Canada's domestic market to foreign competition. Farmers in these sectors have sought compensation for these concessions, arguing that their livelihoods and the stability of the supply management system are at risk. The Liberal platform explicitly states a commitment to defend supply management and provide 'full and fair compensation' for these impacts, recognizing the economic challenges faced by these industries and aiming to ensure their long-term stability and predictability. This promise is a direct response to industry advocacy and a continuation of previous government support for these sectors.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Farmers in supply-managed sectors will receive financial support to offset market access concessions from CUSMA, stabilizing their income and ensuring the viability of their operations against international competition.
Canadians may continue to experience stable prices for dairy, poultry, and egg products due to the managed supply system, which aims to balance producer income with consumer access to goods.

Taxpayers will bear the financial cost of this compensation, as public funds are allocated to support these specific agricultural industries, which could otherwise be directed to other public services.
This policy reinforces Canada's commitment to its supply management system, potentially influencing future trade negotiations where other nations might seek further market liberalization.

It contributes to domestic food security by supporting the continued operation of Canadian farms in these key sectors, potentially reducing reliance on imported goods and ensuring a stable domestic supply.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Reinforces a protected sector structure, potentially limiting competitiveness and economic freedom, with multi-billion dollar compensation impacting fiscal balance, negatively aligning with core tenets.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Ban the live export of horses for slaughter.
semantic_matches.promise_description: This commitment proposes to prohibit the commercial transportation of live horses from Canada to other countries specifically for the purpose of being slaughtered for meat, addressing animal welfare concerns associated with long-distance travel and the slaughter process.

commitment_history_rationale.action: Private Member's Bill C-355, 'An Act to amend the Health of Animals Act (live export of horses),' was introduced for its first reading by MP Alex Atamanenko. This bill sought to prohibit the live export of horses for slaughter, demonstrating early parliamentary efforts and public concern on the issue.

E-petition e-2574, sponsored by MP Alistair MacGregor, closed for signatures with over 18,000 signatories. The petition called on the Government of Canada to ban the live export of horses for slaughter, highlighting significant public pressure and advocacy on the issue.

The Government of Canada tabled its official response to e-petition e-2574. The response acknowledged public concerns regarding the welfare of horses during live export for slaughter and outlined the Canadian Food Inspection Agency's (CFIA) role in enforcing animal transport regulations, confirming the government's awareness of the issue and public demand.

promise_full.text: Ban the live export of horses for slaughter.
promise_full.progress_summary: The provided evidence does not indicate any progress towards banning the live export of horses for slaughter. The documented government actions include measures related to potato wart, general food system protection, international agricultural meetings, dairy producer grants, a grocery sector code of conduct, amendments to grain regulations, and a statement on canola exports. While an order enabling regulations for 'new animals' under the Agricultural Growth Act was noted, there is no specific evidence of legislative introduction, regulatory development, or concrete steps taken to implement the ban on live horse exports for slaughter.
promise_full.concise_title: Prohibit Live Horse Export for Slaughter
promise_full.description: This commitment proposes to prohibit the commercial transportation of live horses from Canada to other countries specifically for the purpose of being slaughtered for meat, addressing animal welfare concerns associated with long-distance travel and the slaughter process.
what_it_means_for_canadians: For animal welfare advocates and the general public, this means an end to a practice widely considered inhumane, aligning Canada more closely with international animal protection standards.
Horse owners and the equestrian industry might see a shift in the market for unwanted or retired horses, potentially leading to increased costs for humane euthanasia or alternative rehoming options.
Producers and exporters involved in the horse meat trade will face a complete cessation of their business model, requiring them to pivot to different agricultural activities or exit the industry.
It reinforces Canada's image as a nation committed to animal rights, potentially influencing trade relations or public perception on other animal welfare issues.
promise_full.background_and_context: This commitment, found in the 2021 Liberal Platform under 'Protecting Animals,' arises from long-standing concerns among animal welfare organizations and the public regarding the treatment of horses during live export for slaughter. Activists have highlighted the stressful and often cruel conditions horses endure during long journeys by air or sea to countries where horse meat is consumed. The Liberal platform acknowledges the need to address these ethical considerations and improve animal welfare standards. The ban aims to prevent suffering associated with these exports, aligning with broader societal demands for more humane treatment of animals in agricultural and trade practices.
intended_impact_and_objectives: For animal welfare advocates and the general public, this means an end to a practice widely considered inhumane, aligning Canada more closely with international animal protection standards.
Horse owners and the equestrian industry might see a shift in the market for unwanted or retired horses, potentially leading to increased costs for humane euthanasia or alternative rehoming options.
Producers and exporters involved in the horse meat trade will face a complete cessation of their business model, requiring them to pivot to different agricultural activities or exit the industry.
It reinforces Canada's image as a nation committed to animal rights, potentially influencing trade relations or public perception on other animal welfare issues.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Banning a specific export market has limited scale and negatively impacts exports and economic freedom relative to core tenets.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Explore next steps to modernize the Canada Grain Act.
semantic_matches.promise_description: This commitment involves exploring future actions to update the Canada Grain Act, a federal legislation governing the handling, grading, and inspection of grain in Canada, with the goal of ensuring it effectively serves both grain producers and the broader grain industry.

commitment_history_rationale.action: Enactment of Bill C-45 (Jobs, Growth and Long-term Prosperity Act), which included significant amendments to the Canada Grain Act, particularly regarding the Canadian Grain Commission's role and producer payment protection.
Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada launched a public consultation to review the Canada Grain Act, seeking input from stakeholders on potential updates and improvements to the Act.

The House of Commons Standing Committee on Agriculture and Agri-Food released its report 'The Canada Grain Act: A Modern Vision,' recommending specific changes to modernize the Act following extensive consultations.

The Government of Canada tabled its response to the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Agri-Food's report 'The Canada Grain Act: A Modern Vision,' acknowledging the recommendations and indicating ongoing consideration of the issues raised.

promise_full.text: Explore next steps to modernize the Canada Grain Act.
promise_full.progress_summary: The government has made major progress in exploring next steps to modernize the Canada Grain Act. Regulations directly amending the Canada Grain Act came into force in August 2022. Additionally, substantial regulatory changes to the Canada Grain Regulations have been approved and enacted. These include a miscellaneous program of technical adjustments, amendments to grain moisture shrinkage calculation rules for terminal elevators, and improvements to soybean grading and barley variety identification. These actions demonstrate concrete steps taken to update and refine the legislative and regulatory framework governing the Canadian grain industry.
promise_full.description: This commitment involves exploring future actions to update the Canada Grain Act, a federal legislation governing the handling, grading, and inspection of grain in Canada, with the goal of ensuring it effectively serves both grain producers and the broader grain industry.
what_it_means_for_canadians: For Canadian farmers, this modernization could lead to more efficient grain handling processes, potentially reducing administrative burdens and ensuring fairer pricing mechanisms for their crops, ultimately improving their profitability and competitiveness.

Consumers and the wider economy may benefit from a more robust and reliable grain supply chain, which could translate to stable food prices and enhance Canada's reputation as a consistent supplier of high-quality grain globally.

However, the modernization process might introduce new regulations or standards that could require initial investments from some grain handlers or producers, potentially leading to short-term adjustment costs or resistance from certain industry stakeholders.

Increased clarity and adaptability in the Act could also help Canada's grain sector respond better to global market changes and climate challenges, securing long-term food security and export opportunities.
promise_full.background_and_context: The commitment to modernize the Canada Grain Act stems from the Liberal Party's broader goal outlined in their 2021 platform to support Canadian farmers and food processors. The platform highlighted the need to strengthen supply chains, reduce costs, and ensure the agricultural sector is well-positioned for the future. The existing Act, enacted decades ago, may contain provisions that no longer fully align with modern farming practices, technological advancements in grain handling, or current market dynamics. Therefore, this commitment seeks to update the legislation to ensure it remains relevant and effective, working optimally for both individual grain producers and the entire grain industry, ultimately enhancing the competitiveness and resilience of Canada's vital grain sector.
intended_impact_and_objectives: For Canadian farmers, this modernization could lead to more efficient grain handling processes, potentially reducing administrative burdens and ensuring fairer pricing mechanisms for their crops, ultimately improving their profitability and competitiveness.

Consumers and the wider economy may benefit from a more robust and reliable grain supply chain, which could translate to stable food prices and enhance Canada's reputation as a consistent supplier of high-quality grain globally.

However, the modernization process might introduce new regulations or standards that could require initial investments from some grain handlers or producers, potentially leading to short-term adjustment costs or resistance from certain industry stakeholders.

Increased clarity and adaptability in the Act could also help Canada's grain sector respond better to global market changes and climate challenges, securing long-term food security and export opportunities.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Exploring modernization of a key act for a major export sector aligns with improving productivity and exports, showing medium relevance and scale.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Develop a sector-specific Agricultural Labour Strategy to address labour shortages.
semantic_matches.promise_description: This commitment aims to develop a tailored strategy specifically for the agricultural sector to address the persistent issue of labour shortages, ensuring Canadian farmers have the necessary workforce to sustain food production, where 'sector-specific' means uniquely designed for agriculture's needs and 'labour shortages' refers to insufficient available workers.

commitment_history_rationale.action: The House of Commons Standing Committee on Agriculture and Agri-Food (AGRI) released its report 'The Agri-Food Labour Shortage: A National Crisis,' detailing the severity of labour shortages across the sector and recommending a national strategy to address the issue.

The Government of Canada announced measures to support temporary foreign workers and employers during the COVID-19 pandemic, including those in the agricultural sector, acknowledging their essential role and the challenges faced in maintaining the food supply chain.

The Canadian Agricultural Human Resource Council (CAHRC) released its 'Sowing the Seeds of Change: A Report on the Labour Market Information (LMI) Study for the Agriculture Sector,' providing comprehensive data on the extent of labour shortages and future labour needs in Canadian agriculture.

promise_full.text: Develop a sector-specific Agricultural Labour Strategy to address labour shortages.
promise_full.progress_summary: Based solely on the provided evidence, no direct progress has been made towards developing a sector-specific Agricultural Labour Strategy to address labour shortages. The evidence primarily details regulations concerning chicken marketing quotas, grain handling, and announcements of specific agricultural funds (e.g., Dairy Innovation, African Swine Fever preparedness), or general support for farmers. There is no mention of consultations, studies, policy development, or legislative initiatives specifically related to an agricultural labour strategy.
promise_full.description: This commitment aims to develop a tailored strategy specifically for the agricultural sector to address the persistent issue of labour shortages, ensuring Canadian farmers have the necessary workforce to sustain food production, where 'sector-specific' means uniquely designed for agriculture's needs and 'labour shortages' refers to insufficient available workers.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Farmers will likely experience reduced operational stress and improved stability due to a more reliable workforce, potentially leading to increased productivity and competitiveness in the agricultural sector.
Canadian consumers may benefit from a more consistent and secure domestic food supply, which could help stabilize food prices and ensure the availability of Canadian-grown produce and products.

The strategy might increase reliance on temporary foreign workers, raising important considerations about their equitable treatment, working conditions, and the potential impact on domestic employment opportunities if not carefully managed.
Rural communities could see economic benefits through a stronger agricultural sector, including job creation within farming and related industries, contributing to local prosperity and investment.

Successful implementation requires complex coordination between various levels of government and industry stakeholders, and delays or insufficient measures could perpetuate existing labour challenges for farmers.
promise_full.background_and_context: This commitment emerged from the recognition of persistent and significant labour shortages within Canada's agricultural sector, a critical issue highlighted in the 2021 Liberal Platform, page 101. Farmers have long struggled to find and retain sufficient workers, impacting their ability to plant, harvest, and process food, which threatens overall food security and the sector's economic viability. The promise to develop a 'sector-specific Agricultural Labour Strategy' is intended to provide targeted solutions to these unique challenges. The 2025 Liberal Platform reinforces this by noting continued efforts to address labour shortages, specifically mentioning the permanent Agri-Food Immigration Pilot, indicating that immigration is a key component of the ongoing strategy to ensure Canadian farmers have the support needed to continue feeding the nation.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Farmers will likely experience reduced operational stress and improved stability due to a more reliable workforce, potentially leading to increased productivity and competitiveness in the agricultural sector.
Canadian consumers may benefit from a more consistent and secure domestic food supply, which could help stabilize food prices and ensure the availability of Canadian-grown produce and products.

The strategy might increase reliance on temporary foreign workers, raising important considerations about their equitable treatment, working conditions, and the potential impact on domestic employment opportunities if not carefully managed.
Rural communities could see economic benefits through a stronger agricultural sector, including job creation within farming and related industries, contributing to local prosperity and investment.

Successful implementation requires complex coordination between various levels of government and industry stakeholders, and delays or insufficient measures could perpetuate existing labour challenges for farmers.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Addresses labour shortages in a key sector, boosting productivity and exports. Has significant scale and positive alignment with core economic tenets.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Introduce legislation to end testing on animals.
semantic_matches.promise_description: This commitment, as stated, proposes to introduce legislation aimed at ceasing all forms of testing on animals, meaning live animal subjects would no longer be used for product or scientific evaluations. However, the provided Liberal platform documents (2021 & 2025) specifically commit only to banning cosmetic testing on animals and the sale of cosmetics tested on animals.

commitment_history_rationale.action: Senator Carolyn Stewart Olsen introduced Bill S-214, the Cruelty-Free Cosmetics Act, in the Senate. This private member's bill aimed to ban cosmetic animal testing and the sale of cosmetics tested on animals in Canada.

Bill S-214, the Cruelty-Free Cosmetics Act, passed third reading in the Senate and was sent to the House of Commons, demonstrating significant parliamentary support for ending cosmetic animal testing.

Health Canada issued a statement expressing support for ending cosmetic animal testing in Canada and committing to work with stakeholders towards this goal, following the Senate's passage of Bill S-214.

The Liberal Party of Canada's 2019 election platform included a commitment to 'Ban cosmetic testing on animals and the sale of cosmetics tested on animals, as well as work with international partners on a modern approach to chemical safety assessment.'

promise_full.text: Introduce legislation to end testing on animals.
promise_full.progress_summary: Based on the provided evidence, no specific government actions or legislative initiatives directly related to introducing legislation to end testing on animals have been identified. While one news release broadly mentions 'strengthening animal protection legislation and practices,' it does not specify any measures concerning animal testing. Other evidence pertains to unrelated health regulations, animal health issues (e.g., avian influenza, hatchery standards, compensation for destroyed animals), or tobacco/vaping products. Therefore, no discernible progress towards this specific commitment is evident.
promise_full.description: This commitment, as stated, proposes to introduce legislation aimed at ceasing all forms of testing on animals, meaning live animal subjects would no longer be used for product or scientific evaluations. However, the provided Liberal platform documents (2021 & 2025) specifically commit only to banning cosmetic testing on animals and the sale of cosmetics tested on animals.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Should a broad ban be enacted, Canadians would see a significant ethical shift, aligning with growing public sentiment against animal cruelty by ending the use of animals in various product and scientific tests.
Consumers might encounter products developed using alternative, potentially novel, testing methods, which could influence product availability or cost across various industries.
Industries reliant on animal testing, such as pharmaceuticals or chemical development, would face substantial regulatory changes, potentially impacting research timelines and innovation.
If limited to cosmetics, Canadians would gain access to a wider range of cruelty-free products, aligning with international standards already adopted by many countries.
The focus on alternatives could spur Canadian innovation in non-animal research techniques, potentially creating new economic opportunities in biotechnologies.
promise_full.background_and_context: The Liberal platform documents (2021 and 2025) commit to banning cosmetic testing on animals and the sale of cosmetics tested on animals. This specific commitment is presented as aligning with measures already in place in many other countries and addresses a growing global trend towards more ethical product development. It reflects a response to public demand for cruelty-free products and aims to ensure Canada's regulations are consistent with international best practices regarding animal welfare in the cosmetics industry.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Should a broad ban be enacted, Canadians would see a significant ethical shift, aligning with growing public sentiment against animal cruelty by ending the use of animals in various product and scientific tests.
Consumers might encounter products developed using alternative, potentially novel, testing methods, which could influence product availability or cost across various industries.
Industries reliant on animal testing, such as pharmaceuticals or chemical development, would face substantial regulatory changes, potentially impacting research timelines and innovation.
If limited to cosmetics, Canadians would gain access to a wider range of cruelty-free products, aligning with international standards already adopted by many countries.
The focus on alternatives could spur Canadian innovation in non-animal research techniques, potentially creating new economic opportunities in biotechnologies.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: A regulatory change with limited direct relevance to national economic tenets and negligible scale of impact on prosperity, making it weak.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Advance legislation to enhance the powers of the Financial Consumer Agency of Canada to review bank fees and charges and to require adjustments if they are excessive.
semantic_matches.promise_description: This commitment proposes new legislation to grant the Financial Consumer Agency of Canada (FCAC), an independent body protecting financial consumers, enhanced authority to scrutinize bank fees and charges and mandate their reduction if deemed excessive, aiming to ensure fairness for consumers.

commitment_history_rationale.action: The Financial Consumer Agency of Canada (FCAC) released its 'Review of Retail Sales Practices in Canada’s Six Largest Banks' report, identifying weaknesses in banks' sales practices and recommending actions to improve consumer protection, which highlighted the need for enhanced FCAC oversight.

The Liberal Party of Canada's 2019 election platform, 'Forward: A Real Plan for the Middle Class,' committed to strengthening the powers of the Financial Consumer Agency of Canada (FCAC) to ensure banks treat customers fairly, including by reviewing bank fees and charges.

The Mandate Letter to the Minister of Finance (Bill Morneau) following the 2019 federal election included a commitment to 'strengthen the powers of the Financial Consumer Agency of Canada to ensure that banks are treating their customers fairly, including by reviewing bank fees and charges.'

promise_full.text: Advance legislation to enhance the powers of the Financial Consumer Agency of Canada to review bank fees and charges and to require adjustments if they are excessive.
promise_full.progress_summary: No direct progress has been made on the commitment to advance legislation enhancing the Financial Consumer Agency of Canada's powers to review and adjust bank fees. The provided evidence includes a general statement from the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance highlighting an ongoing commitment to fair and affordable banking options, particularly regarding credit card practices. However, this statement does not indicate any legislative action, specific initiatives, or direct engagement with the FCAC's mandate as outlined in the commitment. All other evidence items are unrelated to this specific commitment.
promise_full.concise_title: Strengthen FCAC to Review and Adjust Excessive Bank Fees
promise_full.description: This commitment proposes new legislation to grant the Financial Consumer Agency of Canada (FCAC), an independent body protecting financial consumers, enhanced authority to scrutinize bank fees and charges and mandate their reduction if deemed excessive, aiming to ensure fairness for consumers.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Canadians could see a reduction in various bank fees, including those for everyday transactions, credit cards, or account maintenance, potentially leading to direct cost savings.
This initiative aims to increase transparency in banking fee structures, making it easier for consumers to understand and compare charges and potentially preventing the imposition of hidden fees.

The enhanced oversight by the FCAC provides a stronger mechanism for consumer protection, ensuring an independent body is actively safeguarding financial interests against unfair or excessive charges.
Banks might explore alternative revenue streams or adjust services to offset potential income losses from regulated fees, which could indirectly impact the range or quality of some banking services.
The process of defining and enforcing 'excessive' fees could be complex and potentially lead to disputes or delays, though the intent is to ensure fairer banking practices.
promise_full.background_and_context: This commitment arises from a broader Liberal platform objective, highlighted in both the 2021 'Forward For Everyone' and 2025 'Canada Strong' documents, to make life more affordable for Canadians. The platform identifies 'hidden fees and unfair charges' from financial institutions as a concern impacting consumers' financial well-being. The government aims to protect Canadians by enhancing the powers of the Financial Consumer Agency of Canada (FCAC), an existing independent body, to directly intervene in bank fee structures. This initiative reflects a societal need for stronger consumer protection in the financial sector and a belief that an independent oversight body should have the authority to ensure banking services remain fair and accessible, preventing excessive charges.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Canadians could see a reduction in various bank fees, including those for everyday transactions, credit cards, or account maintenance, potentially leading to direct cost savings.
This initiative aims to increase transparency in banking fee structures, making it easier for consumers to understand and compare charges and potentially preventing the imposition of hidden fees.

The enhanced oversight by the FCAC provides a stronger mechanism for consumer protection, ensuring an independent body is actively safeguarding financial interests against unfair or excessive charges.
Banks might explore alternative revenue streams or adjust services to offset potential income losses from regulated fees, which could indirectly impact the range or quality of some banking services.
The process of defining and enforcing 'excessive' fees could be complex and potentially lead to disputes or delays, though the intent is to ensure fairer banking practices.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Focuses on regulating bank fees, showing limited direct impact on national productivity, investment, or competitiveness, and introduces more regulation.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Carry out consultations to inform an approach to applying Border Carbon Adjustments to imports from countries that are not doing their part to reduce carbon pollution and fight climate change.
semantic_matches.promise_description: The government will hold consultations to develop a method for implementing Border Carbon Adjustments (BCAs), which are tariffs on imports from nations that do not adequately reduce carbon pollution, ensuring Canadian businesses are not disadvantaged by their commitment to cleaner production and preventing carbon leakage.

commitment_history_rationale.action: The Greenhouse Gas Pollution Pricing Act (GGPPA) received Royal Assent, establishing a federal carbon pollution pricing system. This created the domestic carbon pricing context that motivated the later exploration of Border Carbon Adjustments to address carbon leakage and competitiveness concerns.

The Fall Economic Statement 2020 announced the Government of Canada's intention to "explore the potential of border carbon adjustments to address carbon leakage and level the playing field for Canadian businesses."

The Government of Canada released "A Healthy Environment and a Healthy Economy," a strengthened climate plan that reiterated the commitment to explore Border Carbon Adjustments (BCAs) to address carbon leakage and ensure a level playing field for Canadian businesses operating under a carbon price.

promise_full.text: Carry out consultations to inform an approach to applying Border Carbon Adjustments to imports from countries that are not doing their part to reduce carbon pollution and fight climate change.
promise_full.progress_summary: No evidence was provided to indicate that consultations have been carried out to inform an approach to applying Border Carbon Adjustments. While several trade-related actions, including the application of tariffs and amendments to trade regulations, were noted, none of these actions are explicitly linked to the commitment of addressing carbon pollution from other countries through border carbon adjustments. The evidence primarily details general trade policy, free trade agreements, and measures against unfair trade practices or in response to foreign tariffs, rather than specific steps toward a carbon-focused border adjustment mechanism.
promise_full.concise_title: Consultations for Border Carbon Adjustments on High-Carbon Imports
promise_full.description: The government will hold consultations to develop a method for implementing Border Carbon Adjustments (BCAs), which are tariffs on imports from nations that do not adequately reduce carbon pollution, ensuring Canadian businesses are not disadvantaged by their commitment to cleaner production and preventing carbon leakage.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Canadian businesses that invest in carbon reduction may experience fairer competition against imports from countries with lower environmental standards, potentially encouraging domestic green innovation and job creation.
Consumers might face slightly higher prices on certain imported goods, particularly those from nations with less stringent climate policies, if the BCA costs are passed on, impacting affordability.
This policy could potentially lead to trade disputes or retaliatory tariffs from affected countries, which might complicate Canada's international trade relations and export markets.
It signals Canada's strong commitment to global climate action, potentially incentivizing other nations to adopt more robust carbon reduction policies to avoid these border adjustments.

Implementing and managing a Border Carbon Adjustment system will be complex, requiring robust frameworks to accurately assess the carbon intensity of imports and avoid unintended economic consequences.
promise_full.background_and_context: This commitment was made to address concerns that Canadian businesses, subject to domestic carbon pricing and stringent climate policies, might be at a competitive disadvantage against imports from countries with less ambitious carbon reduction efforts. This situation could lead to "carbon leakage," where production shifts to places with weaker environmental regulations, ultimately undermining global climate goals. The Liberal platform explicitly states the Border Carbon Adjustment (BCA) is intended to level the playing field, ensuring international competitors face a similar carbon cost at the border as Canadian companies do domestically. This commitment reflects a broader strategy to integrate climate action with economic competitiveness and prevent the erosion of Canadian industries due to climate policy. The consultation phase indicates a careful, informed approach to implementing such a complex trade and environmental mechanism.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Canadian businesses that invest in carbon reduction may experience fairer competition against imports from countries with lower environmental standards, potentially encouraging domestic green innovation and job creation.
Consumers might face slightly higher prices on certain imported goods, particularly those from nations with less stringent climate policies, if the BCA costs are passed on, impacting affordability.
This policy could potentially lead to trade disputes or retaliatory tariffs from affected countries, which might complicate Canada's international trade relations and export markets.
It signals Canada's strong commitment to global climate action, potentially incentivizing other nations to adopt more robust carbon reduction policies to avoid these border adjustments.

Implementing and managing a Border Carbon Adjustment system will be complex, requiring robust frameworks to accurately assess the carbon intensity of imports and avoid unintended economic consequences.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Explores a policy with significant national scale affecting trade and competitiveness. However, introducing border adjustments adds complexity and potential trade friction, counter to tenets promoting economic freedom and export growth.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Introduce legislation to eradicate forced labour from Canadian Supply Chains and ensure that Canadian businesses operating abroad do not contribute to human rights abuses.
semantic_matches.promise_description: This commitment involves introducing legislation to eliminate forced labour from all Canadian supply chains, meaning the entire process of producing and distributing goods, and ensuring that Canadian companies operating in other countries do not participate in or benefit from human rights abuses.

commitment_history_rationale.action: The *Customs Tariff* was amended to prohibit the importation of goods manufactured or produced wholly or in part by forced labour, as part of the implementation of the Canada-United States-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA).

The Subcommittee on International Human Rights (SDIR) of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and International Development (FAAE) released its report 'A Call to Action: Ending the Complicity of Canadian Companies in Forced Labour in Global Supply Chains,' recommending legislative and policy measures.

Senator Leo Housakos introduced Bill S-211, *An Act to enact the Fighting Against Forced Labour and Child Labour in Supply Chains Act and to amend the Customs Tariff* (often referred to as the Modern Slavery Act), in the Senate.

promise_full.text: Introduce legislation to eradicate forced labour from Canadian Supply Chains and ensure that Canadian businesses operating abroad do not contribute to human rights abuses.
promise_full.progress_summary: No direct progress is evident towards the commitment to introduce legislation to eradicate forced labour from Canadian supply chains. The provided evidence includes a statement on a domestic labour dispute, regulations imposing sanctions on Belarus for human rights violations (a foreign policy measure), and diplomatic statements unrelated to the commitment. There is no evidence of relevant legislation being introduced, consultations launched, or specific policy development related to this commitment.
promise_full.concise_title: Eradicating Forced Labour in Supply Chains
promise_full.description: This commitment involves introducing legislation to eliminate forced labour from all Canadian supply chains, meaning the entire process of producing and distributing goods, and ensuring that Canadian companies operating in other countries do not participate in or benefit from human rights abuses.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Canadians can have greater confidence that the products they purchase are not made using forced labour, aligning consumption with ethical values and promoting human rights globally.

It reinforces Canada's reputation as a leader in human rights on the international stage, potentially influencing other countries to adopt similar standards and fostering more ethical global trade practices.

Businesses may face increased compliance costs and due diligence requirements to thoroughly audit their supply chains, potentially leading to higher consumer prices for some goods or changes in sourcing strategies.
The legislation's effectiveness will depend on robust enforcement mechanisms and international cooperation, as tracking complex global supply chains and verifying labour practices can be challenging.
promise_full.background_and_context: This commitment stems from Canada's broader dedication to upholding human rights globally and ensuring Canadian businesses operating abroad adhere to ethical standards. The issue of forced labour in global supply chains has gained increasing international attention, with concerns about products made using exploitative practices entering markets. This legislation aims to address these moral and ethical concerns, building on previous government actions like establishing the Canadian Ombudsperson for Responsible Enterprise (CORE). It reflects a societal expectation that Canadian consumers and businesses should not inadvertently support human rights abuses through their economic activities, reinforcing Canada's role as a responsible global actor.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Canadians can have greater confidence that the products they purchase are not made using forced labour, aligning consumption with ethical values and promoting human rights globally.

It reinforces Canada's reputation as a leader in human rights on the international stage, potentially influencing other countries to adopt similar standards and fostering more ethical global trade practices.

Businesses may face increased compliance costs and due diligence requirements to thoroughly audit their supply chains, potentially leading to higher consumer prices for some goods or changes in sourcing strategies.
The legislation's effectiveness will depend on robust enforcement mechanisms and international cooperation, as tracking complex global supply chains and verifying labour practices can be challenging.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Focuses on ethical supply chains, showing limited direct alignment with core economic tenets. The national economic scale of impact is likely small and indirect. Direction is neutral.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Modernize and strengthen the Pest Control Products Act.
semantic_matches.promise_description: The commitment aims to update and reinforce the Pest Control Products Act, which regulates pesticides, ensuring future decisions on these products are based on the latest scientific evidence, prioritizing public health, environmental protection, and sustainable agricultural practices in Canada.

commitment_history_rationale.action: The Commissioner of the Environment and Sustainable Development (CESD) released Report 3—Pesticide Management, highlighting weaknesses in Health Canada’s oversight of pesticides, including re-evaluations and compliance, suggesting a need for stronger regulation.

The House of Commons Standing Committee on Environment and Sustainable Development (ENVI) released its report 'The Effectiveness of the Pest Management Regulatory Agency,' recommending significant changes to strengthen the Pest Control Products Act (PCPA) and the PMRA's regulatory framework.

Health Canada announced a targeted review of the Pest Management Regulatory Agency (PMRA) and the Pest Control Products Act (PCPA) to address concerns regarding the pesticide approval process, transparency, and the protection of health and the environment.

Health Canada published the 'Report on the Targeted Review of the Pest Management Regulatory Agency (PMRA) and the Pest Control Products Act (PCPA),' outlining findings and recommendations for improving the pesticide regulatory system, including strengthening the Act.

promise_full.text: Modernize and strengthen the Pest Control Products Act.
promise_full.progress_summary: The government has made major progress in modernizing and strengthening the Pest Control Products Act. Regulations were enacted to amend the Act, addressing health and safety concerns of ultraviolet radiation-emitting and ozone-generating devices (May 2022), and modernizing elements related to applications and imports of pest control products (December 2022). New Biocides Regulations, enacted under the Act, came into force (June 2024), establishing a new regulatory framework. Additionally, an order was made to list specific formulants and contaminants of health or environmental concern under the Act (September 2024). Federal departments also announced next steps for a sustainable approach to pesticide management (June 2023).
promise_full.description: The commitment aims to update and reinforce the Pest Control Products Act, which regulates pesticides, ensuring future decisions on these products are based on the latest scientific evidence, prioritizing public health, environmental protection, and sustainable agricultural practices in Canada.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Canadians can expect enhanced public health and safety through stricter, science-based regulation of pesticides, reducing exposure to potentially harmful chemicals in food and the environment.
The environment will benefit from reduced pesticide runoff and impact on biodiversity, leading to healthier ecosystems, cleaner water sources, and better protection for wildlife.
Farmers may face adjustments to practices and potentially increased costs for compliant pest control solutions, though the aim is to support long-term agricultural sustainability and innovation.
Consumers might see a slight increase in food costs if new regulations significantly raise production expenses for farmers, though this is balanced against health and environmental benefits.
promise_full.background_and_context: This commitment arises from a recognition of the evolving scientific understanding regarding the impacts of pesticides on human health and the environment. The existing Pest Control Products Act, which governs the regulation of pesticides, requires updating to reflect the latest scientific evidence. The goal is to ensure that decisions on pesticide use are made with the most current knowledge, thereby enhancing public health protection and mitigating environmental harm. Furthermore, the commitment aims to support the long-term sustainability of Canadian agriculture by providing a clear, science-based regulatory framework that balances production needs with ecological integrity. It aligns with broader government efforts to strengthen environmental protections and promote sustainable practices across various sectors.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Canadians can expect enhanced public health and safety through stricter, science-based regulation of pesticides, reducing exposure to potentially harmful chemicals in food and the environment.
The environment will benefit from reduced pesticide runoff and impact on biodiversity, leading to healthier ecosystems, cleaner water sources, and better protection for wildlife.
Farmers may face adjustments to practices and potentially increased costs for compliant pest control solutions, though the aim is to support long-term agricultural sustainability and innovation.
Consumers might see a slight increase in food costs if new regulations significantly raise production expenses for farmers, though this is balanced against health and environmental benefits.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Regulatory change for specific sectors with limited national economic scale. Indirect link to productivity and efficiency tenets, but direction is unclear.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Prevent the introduction of African swine fever within Canadian borders and continue to work on prevention and preparedness measures.
semantic_matches.promise_description: This commitment aims to safeguard Canada's swine industry and agricultural sector from African Swine Fever (ASF), a highly contagious and often fatal viral disease affecting domestic and wild pigs, by implementing robust border control measures and enhancing national preparedness strategies to prevent its entry and spread.

commitment_history_rationale.action: The Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) issued a statement on African Swine Fever, outlining enhanced prevention and preparedness measures in response to the global spread of the disease.

The Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) announced that Budget 2019 proposed $31 million over five years to the CFIA to protect Canada's pork industry from African Swine Fever, enhancing prevention and preparedness measures.

The Minister of Agriculture and Agri-Food, Marie-Claude Bibeau, announced additional measures to prevent African Swine Fever from entering Canada, including increased collaboration with industry and provinces, and enhanced border measures.

The Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) issued a statement on the detection of African Swine Fever in the Dominican Republic, reinforcing the urgency of prevention and preparedness measures for Canada's pork industry due to the disease's proximity to North America.

promise_full.text: Prevent the introduction of African swine fever within Canadian borders and continue to work on prevention and preparedness measures.
promise_full.progress_summary: The government has made major progress on preventing African Swine Fever. The Canadian Food Inspection Agency's National Centre for Foreign Animal Disease was designated a World Organisation for Animal Health Reference Laboratory for ASF in June 2022, significantly enhancing detection and research capabilities. In May 2024, over $9.6 million was committed through the African Swine Fever Industry Preparedness Program (ASFIPP) to fund 29 projects aimed at enhancing industry readiness, with completion by March 2025. These actions demonstrate substantial funding allocation and operational program implementation for prevention and preparedness. Broader animal health regulations also contribute to the overall biosecurity framework.
promise_full.description: This commitment aims to safeguard Canada's swine industry and agricultural sector from African Swine Fever (ASF), a highly contagious and often fatal viral disease affecting domestic and wild pigs, by implementing robust border control measures and enhancing national preparedness strategies to prevent its entry and spread.
what_it_means_for_canadians: Canadian pork producers will benefit from enhanced protection against a devastating disease, safeguarding their livelihoods, export markets, and the stability of the vital agricultural sector.
Consumers can expect continued access to a stable and safe supply of Canadian pork, avoiding potential price hikes or shortages that an outbreak could cause.
Travelers and importers may experience increased scrutiny and stricter regulations at borders, including more thorough inspections to prevent the entry of contaminated products.
Significant government investment will be directed towards biosecurity measures, detector dogs, and research, ensuring national readiness and potentially influencing resource allocation.
Failure to prevent ASF could lead to severe economic losses, export bans, and the culling of millions of pigs, impacting rural economies and Canada's international trade reputation.
promise_full.background_and_context: This commitment arises from the critical need to protect Canada's significant pork industry and broader agricultural economy from African Swine Fever (ASF). ASF is a highly contagious and deadly disease for pigs, with no vaccine or cure, and its introduction could decimate Canadian herds, leading to severe economic losses, export bans, and widespread culling. The Liberal platform acknowledges Canada's strong reputation for high-quality agricultural products and the constant threat of transboundary animal diseases. This proactive measure aims to safeguard animal health, support farmers' livelihoods, and maintain Canada's international trade standing by investing in enhanced border biosecurity, increased detection capabilities, and ongoing prevention and preparedness strategies against this global threat. The 2021 platform specifically highlighted this ongoing concern and necessary vigilance.
intended_impact_and_objectives: Canadian pork producers will benefit from enhanced protection against a devastating disease, safeguarding their livelihoods, export markets, and the stability of the vital agricultural sector.
Consumers can expect continued access to a stable and safe supply of Canadian pork, avoiding potential price hikes or shortages that an outbreak could cause.
Travelers and importers may experience increased scrutiny and stricter regulations at borders, including more thorough inspections to prevent the entry of contaminated products.
Significant government investment will be directed towards biosecurity measures, detector dogs, and research, ensuring national readiness and potentially influencing resource allocation.
Failure to prevent ASF could lead to severe economic losses, export bans, and the culling of millions of pigs, impacting rural economies and Canada's international trade reputation.
promise_full.bc_promise_rank_rationale: Protects a major export industry, preventing significant economic loss and supporting productivity, exports, and investment aligned with core tenets.

semantic_matches.promise_text: Introduce a reciprocal procurement policy that will ensure goods and services are procured from countries that grant Canadian businesses a similar level of market access.
semantic_matches.promise_description: This commitment proposes a reciprocal procurement policy, meaning Canada will prioritize purchasing goods and services from countries that offer Canadian businesses comparable market access, ensuring a level playing field in international trade and leveraging federal spending to open foreign markets.

commitment_history_rationale.action: U.S. President Joe Biden signs Executive Order 14005, 'Ensuring the Future Is Made in All of America by All of America's Workers,' strengthening 'Buy American' provisions for federal procurement. This action significantly increased concerns in Canada about market access for Canadian businesses in the U.S. government procurement market.

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaks with U.S. President Joe Biden, raising concerns about the 'Buy American' policies and emphasizing the importance of integrated North American supply chains and seeking exemptions for Canada. This marked the beginning of high-level Canadian advocacy against the new U.S. procurement measures.

The Liberal Party of Canada releases its 2021 election platform, 'Forward. For Everyone.', which includes a commitment to 'Introduce a reciprocal procurement policy that will ensure goods and services are procured from countries that grant Canadian businesses a similar level of market access.' This commitment directly foreshadowed its inclusion in the subsequent mandate letters.

promise_full.text: Introduce a reciprocal procurement policy that will ensure goods and services are procured from countries that grant Canadian businesses a similar level of market access.
promise_full.progress_summary: The provided evidence does not indicate the introduction or development of a specific reciprocal procurement policy. While the government engaged in various international trade activities, including dispute resolution (e.g., CUSMA dairy, softwood lumber) and signing free trade agreements (e.g., Canada-Ukraine FTA, UK-CPTPP accession) aimed at improving market access, these actions do not directly address the creation or implementation of a policy that links federal procurement decisions to the level of market access granted by other countries to Canadian businesses. General procurement integrity measures were also noted, but are unrelated to the reciprocal nature of the commitment.
promise_full.description: This commitment proposes a reciprocal procurement policy, meaning Canada will prioritize purchasing goods and services from countries that offer Canadian businesses comparable market access, ensuring a level playing field in international trade and leveraging federal spending to open foreign markets.
what_it_means_for_canadians: This policy aims to open new foreign markets for Canadian goods and services, potentially boosting exports, fostering economic growth, and creating more jobs for Canadians in various sectors.
It could ensure Canadian businesses compete on fairer terms globally, reducing disadvantages faced when other countries impose trade barriers while Canada's market remains open.
However, it might lead to higher costs for government procurement if preferred suppliers from non-reciprocal countries are excluded, potentially impacting the efficiency of public spending.
There's a risk of retaliatory measures from non-compliant countries, potentially escalating trade disputes and negatively affecting broader diplomatic and economic relations.
Consumers might indirectly face higher prices for certain imported goods if the policy restricts access to the most cost-effective global suppliers, impacting affordability.
